natural problem: What is the remainder when $2x^2-17x+47$ is divided by $x-5$?
natural solution: \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0& 12   \\ \end{array} \]We cannot divide $12$ by $x-5$ since $12$ has lower degree.
So the quotient is $2x-7$ and the remainder is $\boxed{12}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2*x^2 - 17*x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 12"
shows  "R x = 2*x - 7"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $2x^2-17x+47$ is divided by $x-5$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 \[ \begin{array}{c|cc c} \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x} & -7 \\ \cline{2-4} x-5 & 2x^2 &- 17x &+ 47  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-2x^2} & +10x  \\  \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -7x & +47   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &+ 7x  &-35   \\ 
 \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0& 12   \\ \end{array} \]We cannot divide $12$ by $x-5$ since $12$ has lower degree.
 So the quotient is $2x-7$ and the remainder is $\boxed{12}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2*x^2 - 17*x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 12"
shows  "R x = 2*x - 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $P(x) = 2x^2 - 17x + 47$ and $Q(x) = x - 5$, find a function $R(x)$ such that $P(x) = Q(x)R(x) + 12$ for all real numbers $x$. The function $R(x)$ is $2x - 7$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 2 - 17 * x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + 12"
shows  "R x = (2 * x powr 2 - 17 * x + 47) div (x - 5)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $2x^2-17x+47$ is divided by $x-5$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 \[ \begin{array}{c|cc c} \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x} & -7 \\ \cline{2-4} x-5 & 2x^2 &- 17x &+ 47  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-2x^2} & +10x  \\  \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -7x & +47   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &+ 7x  &-35   \\ 
 \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0& 12   \\ \end{array} \]We cannot divide $12$ by $x-5$ since $12$ has lower degree.
 So the quotient is $2x-7$ and the remainder is $\boxed{12}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 2 - 17 * x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + 12"
shows  "R x = (2 * x powr 2 - 17 * x + 47) div (x - 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given the functions $P(x) = 2x^2 - 17x + 47$ and $Q(x) = x - 5$, find the function $R(x)$ such that $P(x) = Q(x) \cdot R(x) + 12$. The function $R(x)$ is given by the equation $R(x) = \frac{2x^2 - 17x + 47}{x - 5}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2*x powr 2 - 17*x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = R x"
shows  "R x = 12"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $2x^2-17x+47$ is divided by $x-5$? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 \[ \begin{array}{c|cc c} \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x} & -7 \\ \cline{2-4} x-5 & 2x^2 &- 17x &+ 47  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-2x^2} & +10x  \\  \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -7x & +47   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &+ 7x  &-35   \\ 
 \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0& 12   \\ \end{array} \]We cannot divide $12$ by $x-5$ since $12$ has lower degree.
 So the quotient is $2x-7$ and the remainder is $\boxed{12}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2*x powr 2 - 17*x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = R x"
shows  "R x = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the remainder when the quadratic function $2x^2 - 17x + 47$ is divided by the linear function $x - 5$. The remainder is $12$.

fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

a_3.informal problem: Given the functions P(x) = 2x² - 17x + 47 and Q(x) = x - 5, find a function R(x) such that P(x) equals Q(x) multiplied by R(x) plus 12. The solution is R(x) = (2x² - 17x + 47) / (x - 5) + 12.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * (x powr 2) - 17 * x + 47"

 So the quotient is $2x-7$ and the remainder is $\boxed{12}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * (x powr 2) - 17 * x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = 12"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 2 - 17 * x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 12"
shows  "R x = 12"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 \[ \begin{array}{c|cc c} \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x} & -7 \\ \cline{2-4} x-5 & 2x^2 &- 17x &+ 47  \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{-2x^2} & +10x  \\  \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -7x & +47   \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{} &+ 7x  &-35   \\ 
 \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0& 12   \\ \end{array} \]We cannot divide $12$ by $x-5$ since $12$ has lower degree.
 So the quotient is $2x-7$ and the remainder is $\boxed{12}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 2 - 17 * x + 47"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 5"
and h2 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + 12"
shows  "R x = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given the function definitions $P(x) = 2x^2 - 17x + 47$, $Q(x) = x - 5$, and $P(x)$ divides $Q(x)$, with the additional condition that $P(x)$ equals $Q(x)$ times $R(x)$ plus $12$, find $R(x)$. The final answer is $12$.
